dialogues.speaker: A TRAIN ROARS PAST REVEALING IN THE DISTANCE FIVE MET RID
dialogues.text: TOWARD CAMERA along the tracks. In CLOSE F.G. is.the back part of a sign.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: To most of America in 1913, the Age of Innocence had arrived and the stories of the Indian Wars and the Gold.RuSh and the Great Gunfighters had become either barroom ballyhoo or front-porch remiraiscences... .But on both sides of the $io Grande men still lived as thia7 had in the 1 70's and 1 80's -- unchanged. men in a changing land. THEY WEAR THE KHAKI UNIFORMS OF THE UNITED STATES CnVALJR The horses bear the government brand and the saddles are regulation. PIKE BISHOP,. wearing lieutenant's bars, rides slightly a of the others. He rides stiffly; always slightly in pain. Pike is a not unhandsome, leather-faced man in his early forties. A thoughtful, self-educated top gun with a pench for violence who is afraid of nothing - except the. chang in himself and those around him. Make no mistake, Pike Bishop is not a hero -- his values not ours -- he is a gunfighter, a criminal, a bank. robbe killer of men. His sympathies are not for fences, for trolleys.and telegraphs or better schools. He lives outsi and against society because he believes in that way of li and if he has moments of sympathy for others, moments of regret, t hey ' are short lived. He is not a 'good man' according to the righteous... To them he is totally bad, and he wouldn't have it any other way. Next to him DUTCH ENGSTROM wears the uniform of a sergean Dutch is bigГўВЂВћ good-natured with a fast gun hand, str loyalty and, like Pike, a bone deep distaste for rules an regulations. He can sing,. has more than his share of cha but believes in nothing except two men, and Pike is one. Behind them ride two brothers, LYLE and TECTOR GORCH, dressed as corporals. Lyle and Tector are big, tough, hot tempered and sudden. They work together, eat together and

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: sometimes sleep together with the same whore. Brutal, vicious in a fight, illiterate,. they are always pressing for an advantage and once they get it -- they never let g They are without loyalty or honor, to anyone except each other and that is limited. A fifth man wears the single stripe of a PFC. This is. AL Angel is a good-looking, bilingual Mexican boy in his mid 20's who has seen so much blood and violence and cruelty under Diaz that he rebelled -- but his rebellion was not Villa or Obregon, his was a one-man revolution against th all. He believes in his family, his village and the inher dignity of. man (some men at least). " He is faster than companions with a gun -- and a better shot -- but he can' laugh at the loss of love or suffer the loss of pride -- Mexican pride - a pride that can kill him, but if it does he will have no regrets. dialogues.text: You could just ride off -- even join him again -- you'd like that, wouldn't .you?

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: What I like and what I. need are two different things. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Listen -- I don't want to go back to prison, Mr. Harrigan,... .not ever -- but it.has to be my way...

dialogues.speaker: HARR IGAN
dialogues.text: All right..

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: I need good men: You saw what happened today.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIGAN
dialogues.text: (FLATLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll use what you have. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you'll see it doesn't happen again or I'll see you dead or rotting for -the rest of -- you try your life behind bars to run -- I'll be after you and so will. they.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (ANGRY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you my word.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIGAN
dialogues.text: We'll -see what it's worth -- five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: Just more of Texas as far as I'm concerned.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: You have no eyes. And he rises ahead with Pike and'Dutch across the tracks into Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: IT IS A MASS OF DRIED BLOOD WHICH THORNTON WIPES AWAY
dialogues.text: HIS GLOVED HAND, then looks up at the eight bounty hunter who are sitting on their horses watching him.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (wear4.ly) V All rightt... .How many of you killed this one?

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: I knowed I wounded' three -- but I wasn't sure about --

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (as the others yell in

dialogues.speaker: PROTEST
dialogues.text: Jabali:... 111 JABALI, AN AGING NAVAHO INDIAN trots up to.him'.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: This pelt should clear you up -- take him back to town...and tell Harrigan to get me a list of every Army garrison and payroll schedule on the border. (to.the.others, crossing to his horse) We got another half hour of light and they might be just up ahead counting their money.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE AND HIS MEN RIDE INTO THE RUINS OF A SMALL RANCH
dialogues.text: A young boy takes their horses while an old.man and his wounded son (the father of the boy) watch. Behind them, an ancient woman pays no attention as she slaps tortillas into shape. Two small children watch, big-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEIR HORSES.. FREDDY SYKES, a skinny old man in tattered clothes, crosses to Pike as he unloads his saddle bags.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Them others ain't comin'?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (after a moment) None of 'em? 111 PIKE TAKES THE BAGS OUT OF THE CORRAL TO THE FIRE tha near an adobe wall and drops them on a poncho, watches as the others do the same.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (joining him again; worried) But I got horses and gear for all them fellers like you said --

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: They won't need them -- we will. Sykes thinks this over, finally nods. a little and turns 115 LYLE AND HIS BROTHER AND DUTCH STAND in a half. circl the poncho. waiting. Angel, the last, drops his saddle ba then crosses to the wall and drops down to rest. For a lo moment the men look down.a-t the pile of saddle bags.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: About the sharing up...

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (WEARILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sharing up's going to be the some as always.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (whining; pointing to

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Tector and I don? t like the idea of him getting the same as us...He's just starting out and this is our stake for new territory. Pike looks at him silently. He has heard this kind of argument many times in the past and it is obvious he is s to death of it. Lyle finally looks awa- at his brother;

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: And I figure a 'share to that old man for watching the horses is a share too much. ll& PIKE TAKES A KNIFE OUT OF HIS BELT, opens a saddl takes out a sack of silver, kneels to slit the bag open.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: You hear me, Pike? -- I said it ain't fair... Pike stands,. flips the knife into the ground, faces the brothers.

dialogues.speaker: P IKE
dialogues.text: (SOFTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you two boys don't like equal shares why in hell don't you just take it all? They look at him silently. 117 DUTCH DRIFTS AWAY A LITTLE TO TIE SIDE OF PIKE. ГўВЂВ MOVES OUT OF THE BACKGROUND, a buffalo gun now dangling from one arm. The brothers tense. Angel laughs softly.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) Well,..why don't you answer me, you dapnned yellow.-livered trash? The brothers fide, et., look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Ah.--' Pike, you know...

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (his voice a whip) I don't know a damned thing except I either lead this bunch or I end it -- right now;

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: No, sir -- we divide just as you say. Pike looks at them a moment, then picks up his knife and alicea open a bag and -turns it upside down and dumps the contents onto the spread-out poncho watching as:

dialogues.speaker: STEEL WASHERS POUR 01 0 THE PONCHO
dialogues.text: 119 THE GROUP IS SILENT IN DISBEL'EF staring at the pile worthless steel. Hykes eases up, takes a cautious look.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: Rings:, Steel rings! DUTCH. (quietly). Washers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More-washers pour out. _

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Son of a bitch! 121 LYLE'S BOOT FLASHES INTO THE PILE. The washers fly in directions. Lyle whirls on Pike.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Washers...we shot our way out of that town for a dollar's worth of steel holes. He kicks into the pile and scatters Washers across the clearing.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: They set it up:

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (yelling). Who the hell is 'they!!?

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (laughing; cackling) 'They?': by 'they, are just plain and fancy 'they.' 'They.' (dancing around them his high laughter splitting the night) Caught you, didn't they? Tied a tin can to your tail -- didn't they? Lead you in and waltzed you out -- Oh my what a bunch -- big tough ones -- standing around with a handful of holes -- a thumb up your ass and a big grin to pass the time of day with. 122 TECTORSWINGS AT HIM, BUT THE OLD MAN DUCKS, then fall rollsaway, still laughing. Tector starts'to follow, Pike stepsbetween them.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Railroad men -- Pinkertons -- bounty

dialogues.speaker: HUNTERS
dialogues.text: (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Deke Thornton.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (in disbelief ) Deke Thornton? -- He was with. them?

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (as Pike doesn't answer;

dialogues.speaker: QUIETLY
dialogues.text: How come you didn't know?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE TURNS AWAY. DUTCH LOOKS AT PIKE QUESTIONINGLY, T
dialogues.text: ALL TURN as the SOUND of laughter comes from behind. ANGEL IS SITTING AGAINST-THE WALL LAUGHING.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: .(to Tector) Hey, gringo; You take my share. 125 TECTOR WHIRLS, HIS HAND FLASHING FOR HIS GUN.
126 BEFORE HE CAN DRAW ANGEL'S. EXPRESSION TURNS serious gun is suddenly in his hand covering the big outlaw. Ange smiles again...then pleads mockingly.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Don't kill me, gringo ...por favor... Take my share of the 'silver' -- but
don't kill me, please. Tector tenses, almost snarling with rage..

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: ,k for it I Tector-, looking at Angel's gun, half turns to Pike.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (continuing; softly) Go on, fall apart! Lyle and Tector hesitate, their hands on their guns -- Du moves back into the shadows of the firelight, his rifle drifting across Tector. 127 ANGEL SMILES AND SLOWLY replaces his gun.

dialogues.speaker: \ DUTCH
dialogues.text: Let's walk soft, boys...

dialogues.speaker: LYLE, STILL MORE THAN HALF READY TO GO FOR HIS GUN,
dialogues.text: hesitates. 129 TECTOR LOOKS AT PIKE, DUTCH, ANGEL, T.HEN slaps his g his holster -- and moves away, but his hand is never far from the weapon..

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP STANDS MOTIONLESS FOR A MOMENT, THEN SYKES
dialogues.text: INTO HIS COAT, LIFTS OUT A BOTTLE,. SITS BY THE FIRE and hands'it to Dutch. Dutch sits by Sykes, takes a drink, offers the bottle to Tector, Tector hesitates, then hunkers down and drinks. Slowly the others.follow suit.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (as the bottle moves around) What's our next move?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Agua Verde is the closest three days maybe -- then we sell the extra stock -- get some griib and the news and drift back to the border -- maybe a payroll -- maybe abank --

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (GENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that damned railroad:

dialogues.speaker: TEC TOR
dialogues.text: That railroad sire bsi hell ain't getting 4ny easier. ГўВЂВў

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (QUIETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we,ain't getting any younger. For a moment, it looks like he'll get a smart answer in return, then: Lyle drinks and lifts the bottle to Angel who.crosses to. fire,. drinks and passes it to Sykes.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (FINALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .We got to start thinking beyond our guns -- theft days are closin' fast.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (without malice) All your fancy planning and talk damn near got us shot to pieces for.some lousy bags of washers... Now this was goin.' to be our last job before we head south ...We spent all our time and money getting ready for this.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (DRYLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spent your time and money running whores in Hondo while I spent my stake setting it up. LYLE CALMLY PICKS UP A WASHER, flips. it to (or at) Pike catches it, looks at it, through it, drinks, tosses it ba on the pile.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (TRUTHFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like I'd have been better off running whores than making plans9 stealing horses and buying uniforms. 1.32 THE MEN ARE SILENT FOR A LONG MOMENT. Then they brea soft laughter which builds slowly.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) He --.he was making plans while me and Tector was -- He breaks up and can't continue.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (his laughter growing) ,-While you was getting your bell rope pulled by -- (standing; almost choking) By two -- mind you, two -- Hondo whores -- while Pike's dreaming of washers - you're matching two of them -- in tandem And the wild bunch falls apart in laughter -- even Pike i caught, but as he laughs, he knows that they are together again.

dialogues.speaker: T.C.
dialogues.text: How close you figure we are?

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: Not close enough... They're across the border by now. -

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Deke - you rode with. Pike -- what kind of a man are we up against?

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (after a long moment; softly) The best -- (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: THORNTON (CONT tD ) He's never got caught. - (after a moment) And he won't be if you boys don't learn your trade. -

dialogues.speaker: FESS
dialogues.text: How was it -- then mm (as Thornton looks at him) You know -- in the old days? I only come out here last spring.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (after a long moment) You can saddle up or shut up -- take your choice --

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: (after a long moment) "What will he do?

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: That's what I have to figure.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Maybe they'll split up.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: No -- not 'that. bunch. They'll try again. - - T.C. How do you know?' But Thornton doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 134 PIKE AND DUTCH ARE SIDE BY SIDE IN THEIR blankets lis to Angel play the guitar. For several moments they are. silent, then:

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Didn't you run some kind of mine -- in Sonora?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, I helped run a little copper -- nothing for us there except day wages, if it was running now -- which it ain't.

dialogues.speaker: CHANGE
dialogues.text: 2/12/68 3L.. 135 PIKE FINDS IT.IMPOSSIBLE TO get comfortable. Groaning wincing with pain he shifts on the bedroll.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Why in the hell, did you ever quit it?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Why in hell are you still goin'?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: I don.'t know"any better -- maybe don't want any better, (then, after a moment) Hell, I wouldn't know what to do with 'better' if it poked me.in the eye with a sharp stick.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (laughing softly) You -never gave it :a chance9 Pike.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (ANGRY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I threw away more chances in one year that you will see in your whole.l.ife -- but that don't mean you have. to ' be a damn fool like me. Dutch sits up, rolls and lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: You got a halfway hard mouth, partner.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: What in hell do you want me to-say ,-?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Just don't give me, no lectures.. They are silent -- finally:

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: This was going to be my last, too... I'm not getting around any better -- like the red-haired lady said to the. white-haired judge -- 'I only got so many miles left -in my backside, Your Honor, and I aim to keep it moving while I'm still young enough to feel. what it's there for.' (a.s Dutch -laughs softly) I'd like to make a good score -. then back off. CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Back off to what? (as Pike doesn't answer) Any real ideas for a next one? Pike closes his eyes and leans back.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Pershing. has. got men spread over the whole border. Everyone of those garrisons is going to be.gptting payroll.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: That kind of information is kind of. rough to come by.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (sitting up) Well -- I don't figure it's going to .be easy, but it can be done. DUTCH. They'll be waiting for us.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: I wouldn',t have it any other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 136- MOST OF THE BOUNTY HUNTERS ARE ASLEEP, only'Thornton fer are awake. Thornton sits up,.begins to roll a cigaret

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: If he's in old Mex -- do we follow him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Why not ?..

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: He'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Harrigan ' said something about thirty days --

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (after a moment) That's what he said,

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: You must have hurt that railroad pretty bad -- they spent a lot of time and money getting that ambush set up for us.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (smiling at the memory) Well, I caught up to them -- two or three times -- There was a man named Harrigan -- He had a certain way of doing things -- So I made him change his ways -- when you do that to a narrow man -- he can't live with it - from then on he's got to change you -- break you -- just to prove he's.right -- there-'s a hell of a lot of people, Dutch -- that just can't stand to be wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Pride, I guess

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: I guess -- but they can't ever forget it -- that pride that being wrong or learn by it.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (after a long moment) And you -- and me --did we learn -- being wrong today?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (SOFTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I surely hope to God we did. 138 SYKES CROSSES TO PIKE, GIVES HIM a cup of coffee, mov away,

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Where'd you find him?
138 (Cont,)

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: .(softly) That toothless old wreck was a real gun about twenty years back -- used to run with Thornton and me killed his share and more -- around ----Langery -- Ambushed stages all along that old board highway.,.He had those Swede immigrants so scared theyQd starve rather than go to town and by beans for their kids, and there wasn't a sheriff in. the territory to take issue -- He laughs, drinks the coffee and gags..

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he ain't changed -- only now-he does his killing with a coffee cup. Dutch laughs and then both lean back listeningas:

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL, WRAPPED IN HIS SERAPE LEANING AGAINST THE-WAL
dialogues.text: the great ranchero songs of old Mexico., 140 LYLE.AND TECTOR ARE ALSO AWAKE and listening.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (softly) - Pike, I wouldn?t have it no other -way aither.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE AND THE OTHERS, (NOW DRESSED FOR THE TRAIL)
dialogues.text: THE'TOP-OF A HIGH DUNE;. They are tired and dirty. Near the edge they dismount to lead their horses to the bottom. -

dialogues.speaker: 1L.2 THE SAND IS LOOSE AND THE FOOTING EXTREMELY DIFFICUL
dialogues.text: start down in single file, Sykes is last, he leads his ow horse, a pack animal, and three of the empties.
143 SUDDENLY SYKES SLIPS AND LOSES HIS-FOOTING. He falls

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD
dialogues.text: PULLING THE FIVE HORSES DOWN WITH HIM.. Unable to control his slide he collides with/Tector who is next in line. Tector's fall starts a p fain reaction in which all the men slide to the bottom of ttLe hill. 145 PICKING UP SPEED THEY TUMBLE TO THE BOTTOM and land i a giant cloud of. dust. There. is a: profusion of coughin and swearing as the men and-animals struggle to their feet.. 146 TECTOR STANDS,. CURSES AT SYKES,. then picks up a. st and throws it at.the old man who is hit and falls backward. 147 PIKE GRABS TECTOR'AND SWINGS HIM AROU3D...

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Leave him alone!

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: (R'AVING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hats goin' to get pis killed -- get rid of him!

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (his anger growing) We don.'t get rid of nobody we stick together -- just like it used to be -- when you side aman you stay with him -- (shaking him) If you can't do that you're worse than some animal -- you're finished -- we're finished -- all of us! Tector looks at him silently. 148 PIKE TURNS TO MOUNT THE HORSE. Placing his foot in the stirrup he stiffly starts to swing on. The leather breaks and. he falls under the animal. Landing on his back, he lets out a loud shriek.

1.9 THE OTHER N'EN LOOK DOWN AT HIM AS TEEM MOUNT. Dutch, ready to mount his horse hesitates, but doesn't move to help. 150 PIKE STRUGGLES TO HIS FEET. None of them move forward to help him and he doesn't expect them to. He is visibly miserable as he recovers the reins of his animal and tears off the.broken leather. 151 LYLE AND TECTOR GRIN A LITTLE. Sykes turns away.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: (PIOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Pears 'Brother Pike' needs help, Brother Lyle.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Riding with 'Brother Pike' and old .man Sykes makes a man wonder if it ain't time to pick up his chips and-find another game.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: (suddenly yelling at Pike) How in hell are you going to side any- body if you can't get on a horse. 152 PIKE LOOKS AT THEM, THEN STEPS onto the makeshift sti and mounts, concealing his pain, taking a few seconds to gather up the reins and position himself. In the b.g., Dutch swings onto his horse.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Were about two hours from the Santa Caterinas. He turns and rides toward the mountains, the men followin

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: That was a mighty fine talk you gave the boys 'bout stickin' to- gether. (as Pike doesn't

dialogues.speaker: SYKES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That Gorch was near killin' me or me him -- (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned old fool like me's not worth. takin' along.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: We started together -- we'll end it together.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: By God, that's the way I see it -- that's the way it's always been with me...Sorry 'bout Deke - never figured him that way, (then, as Pike doesn't answer) Back in. San. Rafael -- my boy how' d. he do? They ride for a while in silence as: Pike. thinks this ov finally:. _

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Your boy2

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: C.L. -- Clarence Lee -- my daughter's boy ---not too bright, but a good boy -- He handle higself all right? -- I told him -- you do -- just what Mister Bishop says -- Did he conduct hisself well?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (after a long moment) He did fine -- (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me he was your grandson?

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Well, you had enough on your mind He had to pull his weight just like the rest of us -- just wanted to know he didn't let you down -- run. when things got hot --

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) No ---he did fine...just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THORN TON AND THE BOUNTY HITTERS follow the wild bunch's 154 trail. They are hot and tired and with the exception of Thornton,.. are apprehensive. Coffer pulls up, calls to Thornton:

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: That culvert -- good place for them ----to make an ambush.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: Go on - ride up and find out. Coffer hesitates, his -ayes wide with fear. Thornton draw his gun, pulls back the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTO1
dialogues.text: (SAVAGELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go onl Coffer rides forward.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (to the others) Next time I want advice from any of you scum I'll ask for it -- until then, keep . your mouths shut and do what y-ou' re to ld%

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: (turning back, calling) All clear"'--

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON RIDES UP TO THE CULVERTS HALTS, DISMOUN-TS,
dialogues.text: INTO the shade, the others follow suit.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: From here on, its Mexico, Mr, Thornton. T.C. Do we follow?

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: What's the closest town of any size2

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: (POINTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agua Verde -- maybe two or three days. (then, pointing in the apposite direction) Juarez -- five -- six days hard riding,

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: What's in Agua Verde?

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Mexicans -- what else. (then quickly, as Thornton turns on him) Headquarters for Huerta regulars. fighting Obregon, led by an old time bandit named Mapache. Thornton thinks about this, then mounts and rides back in the direction they have come from.

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: Don't-we follow?

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: No -- we wait. T.C. (MOUNTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long --ГўВЂВў Mr. Thornton.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: 'Twenty-eight days.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. DESTROYED HACIENDA (SAN CARLOS)-ГўВЂВў- DAY '156 THE BANDITS ARE RIDING under'a broad sky across thro destroyed pueblo filled with silent ghostlike people, fou or five crying children, vultures and four men hanging from a tree. In the distance is a high range of mountains Angel spurs his horse and rides up beside Pike.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (to Pike) We're not going to find much down here., That damned Huerta' s scraped it clean.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) May he die the death of a thousand traitors. , ( then) My village is up there ...in those mountains.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: So --?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: I wish to visit my f amily...I can do it and meet you in Agua Verde a day of ter you get there.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Going this way, you will. have to turn east when you get south of the range... I-know the way to cross the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: If you know a shorter way..': show us. Angel looks away and is silent for several seconds.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Ashamed of having us meet your people?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (SINCERELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.;..They don' t know about zny life when I am out of the village. Pike and Dutch both laugh softly, then Pike pulls up at a watering trough and dismounts as his horse begins to drin

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Far as Ifm concerned, you can go,

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (dismounting, joining

dialogues.speaker: THEM
dialogues.text: Far as I'm concerned -- he goes he dontt come back.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: That sounds right to me..

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Looks like I'm outvoted.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: (DISMOUNTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatfs the problem?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Wants to visit his folks alone -- thinks we're a little rank for his people.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: (as Tector drinks beside his horse) I think he can go straight to hell.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: Probably wants to get a bunch of his _people and waylay us!

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: And take what? Tector thinks this over, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (to Angel) How do' you want it?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (after a long moment) I invite you to my village -- my home. (then, looking at Tector and Lyle) Any violence -- any disrespect -- and I will. kill you. Tector and Lyle look at him without expression for a mome then:.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: You got a sister?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: ...Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: I would be proud to.make her acquaint- ance -- and. that of your Mama, too.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: (trying not to laugh) And your Grandmaw too, sonny... Angel looks at them, then mounts, rides toward the mounta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 158 THORNTON AND HIS BOUNTY HUNTERS are riding back past where Buck died. The men are sullen,. some almost openly defiant.

dialogues.speaker: T.C.
dialogues.text: We go back with our tail between our legs Harrigan will have our hides.

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: (PATIENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be coming back -- and we'll be waiting for them.

dialogues.speaker: C OFFER
dialogues.text: (WHINING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We was supposed to go after them -- Thornton reins up, looks at Coffer, who looks quickly awa

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: You have something to say? Coffer instantly lifts his hands in submission and shakes his head. Then, after a moment:

dialogues.speaker: COFFER
dialogues.text: They say Freddy Sykes is with them -- you rode with the old man, didn't you, Mr. Thornton -- you and Pike and the old man? But Thornton rides on and doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 159 TECTOR AND LYLE ARE SEATED ON THE GROUND trying to du the intricacies oГ‚ВЈ a very complicated cat's cradle dem strated to them by ROCIO, the lovely bright-eyed 13 year sister of Angel. Both men are drinking tequilla, but both are sober, entranced and completely dominated by the girl All three straighten as: 160 CARMEN, ANGEL'S MOTHER, CALLS from a nearby fire wher is preparing food with her mother.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Miha -- trigame auga.por los frijolesl The girl jumps to her feet, hands both men a bucket (or o and leads.them down the bank to the river. (The natural beauty of this location should contrast with other landsc in the picture. This village and its inhabitants represen a complete and green contrast to the arid world of the wild bunch),

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE, ANGEL'S GRANDFATHER, WATCH SILENTLY. SYKES IS A
dialogues.text: FEW FEET AWAY. Angel watches dully,. his eyes mirroring h agony. Pike laughs softly, watching.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Hard to believe.

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: Not so hard -- we all dream of being a-child again -- even the worst of us -- perhaps the worst most of all..

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (looking: at him) You know us, then --

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: I know myself only -- where I have been, what I have done.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Like to ride with us, old man? And for a moment, the old man's eyes flash as he watches: 162- DUTCH AND THREEVILLAGERS SHOEING a very small, very 16L. mule. All four have been drinking a little and are t enjoying themselves as is the mule as he pitches and knoc them all sprawling..

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: -- I am too old. (almost cursing, indicating

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: .Too old even to ride beside this ancient gringo.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Hell, you ain't so old; partner.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (BITTERLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the soldier. who shot my father what was his name?

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: They were many -- who shot -- your father resisted like a man and died like a man -- names in this matter have no importance. (to Pike proudly) I killed one; (as Pike looks at him) I lie -- I ran --

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Joe --'by God I like you. I like a man who tells the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (IMPATIENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the leader -- how was he called?

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Mapache.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: That is.name enough.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: The Federal. troops they don? t. protect you --

dialogues.speaker: ICON JOSE
dialogues.text: They were Federal troops; -- commissioned by the traitor Huerta -- seven of the village were killed --.our horses and cattle and corn stolen -- all in the name of Huerta, the killer of our President Francisco I.. Madero -- In Mexico, Senor - these are the years of sadness.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (after a long moment,

dialogues.speaker: STANDING
dialogues.text: And Teresa?

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: Gone.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (WHIRLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took her?

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: No -- she went with them because she wished to. She became the woman of Mapache -- and others -- she went with them laughing -- Drunk with wine and love. Angel, knowing it's true, turns and moves away. Pike look after him.'

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE HANDS SYKES THE BOTTLE, SYKES DRINKS, HANDS
dialogues.text: PIKE who drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: To him she was a goddess. To be wor- shipped from afar -- with music and flowers -- a deity to be followed and adored at a dis -nee but Mapache -' knew she was a mango -- ripe and waiting...

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: -So Angel lives with a dream -- while Mapache eats the mango --

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: Just so - ( THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been there -- with the dream?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Many times -- and with the mango too.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: (CACKLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just bet he has, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: I never could carry a candle to you, old timer.

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: (to Pike) And. which do you prefer, the dream or the taste?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: I dream when I sleep -- and eat when I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: (laughing with Sykes) Just so ГўВЂВў -- the both of you and Map-ache and I --

168 ANGEL, SOME DISTANCE AWAY, watches evening come upon quiet village and watches: 169 TECTOR AND LYLE moving from the pond carrying water, surrounded by a dozen laughing children. 70 DUTCH AND THE THREE OLD MEN trying to pound a horsesho an the mule. 1.71 HIS MOTHER AND GRANDMOTHER AND other village women n basting a kid cooking over the coals and: 172 PIKE,. SYKES AND HIS-GRANDFATHER laughing in the rama 17 3 ANGEL TURNS AWAY, his eyes suddenly blind with tears Then,-turns and crosses to his Grandfather..

dialogues.text: Where is Mapache?;

dialogues.text: '17L. THORNTON LEADS THE BOUNTY HUNTERS ALONG THE RAILS t bunkhouse. They have been riding a long time. The men are tired and bitter. Suddenly Coffer draws his gun and point it at Thornton's back.. For a moment it. looks as if he w shoot, then Thornton pulls up sharply,. and kicks his. ho to one side as:

dialogues.speaker: THORNTON
dialogues.text: Ride ahead, all of you. And they do, riding toward Harrigan as we.,

177 TECTOR AND LYLE dance a Mexican Virginia reel as 178 SYKES BLOWS ACCOMPANIMENT with harmonica along with t of the local guitar players.

dialogues.speaker: THE VILLAGERS CHEER THEM ON, THEN TWO PRETTY GIRLS
dialogues.text: AND LINDA) JUMP UP and. dance with the- Gorch brothers, learning the steps from the willing, if surprisingly bashful, teachers.

dialogues.speaker: MURMURING OF CARMALITA, A RATHER PLUMP AND QUITE PRETTY
dialogues.text: YOUNG GIRL, seated between him and Dutch. Angel, across. the fire, raises his voice and repeats the question:. ANGEL. You must tell me.- where Map ache?

dialogues.text: laughing softly to himself, finally turns, his smile fadi

dialogues.speaker: DON JOSE
dialogues.text: Why do you wish to know -- for your father - or the whore? Pike looks up as Angel fights within himself to find an answer,

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (FINALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make any difference, kid our business is in Agua Verde For a moment Angel looks like he will explode, then he lifts a bottle of tequi.lla in salute to Pike.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: As you say, Jefe - to Agua Verde and 'our business.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 182 PIKE AND THE-OTHER It N ARE WATERING THEIR HORSES und shade of several large trees in the main plaza of Agua Ve The town itself is dull and sun colored like. the surroun country. Its most remarkable features are a great deal of soldiers exiting and entering a cantina-like building and a small, aging, ornate, church.

18 3 SYKES PURCHASES A TACO FROM A SMALL BOY and gums at while the contents run into his beard. 18. PIKE LIFTS A STIRRUP FROM HIS SADDLE on the hitching and examines the repair, then puts it on his horse. Tecto and Lyle squat in the shade working at making a cat's cra Angel is talking quietly to three Mexican peons some dist away. ГўВЂВў. 185 DUTCH LEAVES. THE BUILDING and joins Pike.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: All soldiers - not a bounty hunter in sight.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: We'll go. have a drink, then try and sell the horses.

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: 'Who'.s going to buy -- looks to me like. this place has been picked clean.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (joining Pike) He's been here; 186 THE HORSES PUT THEIR EARS BACK and whinny nervously a incredible noise is heard off scene. The men snap their heads.around and look at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STREET towards the plaza. Inside is the almost ghostlike appearance of a 1912 or 1913 touring car. Four mounted me are riding on each side and a host of small.children are running, screaming, behind it.

dialogues.speaker: SIX MEN GET OUT AND TWO OF THEM INSTANTLY BEGIN DUSTING
dialogues.text: AND POLISHING. The mounted guards. take up positions arou the vehicle. The group shows deference to a large man wearing general's braid. -EL 'MAPACHE. Next to him is his second in command, ZAMORRA. The third man dressed in whit linen is MOHR, a German military advisor. With him is ERN his aide. 189 PIKE AND THE OTHERS WATCH with interest as the men en cantina-like building. Then without a word they cross the

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: street, drawn to the vehicle. Angel is tense, knowing that his man has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: I seen one just like this in Waco...

dialogues.speaker: LYLE
dialogues.text: Run on steam?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: No...alcohol:...or gasoline. 190 FREDDY SYKES EDGES UP CLOSE TO PIKE. He is anxious to a. statement and he speaks to him as he walks around the

dialogues.speaker: SYKES
dialogues.text: Pike... .I heard about one they got up north that. kin fly; Pike nods sagely. Te.ctor Gorch on the other side of the car hears the remark.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: (SCORNFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .That was a balloon ,you damned old fool.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: No,. the old man's right. They -got t em now with motors and wings -- cover 60 miles in less than an hour...goin' to use them in the war, they say. (as T(ector looks at him astonished) This could cover. 30 miles in an hour -- ' cording to the road, of course.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: That could run a horse right into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Not that easy -- these automobiles can't stand.any rough ground -- or hot sun like a horse ---they're for show mostly. 191 TECTOR TOUCHES A FENDER AND ONE of the guards spurs t him, cursing in Spanish. Tector backs off,. hands in the

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: I was just going to touch th.,e damn thing, not marry it.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Un gigante de miquina -- Ha de tenor una fuerza tremenda. (A giant of a machine -- What force it must have)

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: -La fuerza.do 1,000 caballos. (The force of 1,000 horses.)

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Y el dueno -- un general por lo menos. (And the owner -- a general at least.)

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Mapache? Mis que un general - un hombre hecho para reinar todo Mexico, si Dios quiere. (Mapache? More than a general -- a man to.rule all of Mexico if God wills.)

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: You're here with us,pardner -- any business you got with the general comes after we finish ours -- and that is selling horses..

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (after a moment, shrugging) As you wish. He turns away, Pike grabs him, jerks him back,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make.one move to trouble and I'll -kill you -- understand -- we stick together.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (before Angel can answer) Angel -- who does this thing belong to?

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (with due respect) Es el carrazo oficial de.su excelencia el Generalisimo Mapache. Dutch turns smiling and tells the others.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: The official carrazo of the Pache Generalisimo. CONTINUED

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Let's get some beer and talk to the general about his automobile and our extra horses,,.nice and easy. The men turn and follow him into the cantina.

dialogues.speaker: THE CANTINA IS A LARGE MANY LEVELED ROOM IN A HALF DE
dialogues.text: HACIENDA FILLED WITH MEXICANS wearing the uniforms of Huerta,' s counter-revolutionary army and their ladies,, A small mariachi band wanders among the. tables. playing songs of the era. In certain areas horses are stabled.-- a blacksmith shop is working, guns are being repaired, kn and bayonets sharpened..,and food is being cooked for the troops by their women. Kids, as .always,. are very eviden 19L. MAPACHE AND HIS GROUP ARE SEATED AT A TABLE which is covered area raised above the others. It is obvious from. his position and respect accorded him that he is the loca .boss of the area.' The German officer, Mohr, and Ernst, 'sitting on one side of him. Lieutenant Zamorra is seated on the other side. Herrera is close by. 1.95. PIKE AND THE OTHERS MOVE TOWARDS A CORNER of the ca eyeing the Mexicans with the kind of caution that men who are vastly outnumbered generally show.. They sit quietly at a table, ignoring the suspicious looks of the soldiers 196 AT MAPACHE'S LONG TABLE, the General and the Germans them with pointed interest. Mohr nudges Mapache and asks who they are. Mapache shr ugs -- he doesn't know, 197 EMMA, A PRETTY WAITRESS, CROSSES TO PIKE'S table to t their order.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Diga?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Beers.. six cervesas,

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Como? Angel remains silent, looking at the General,

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Seii cervesas. The girl leaves to' get the order. The men at the table l around the cantina. At a nearby table a group of men are throwing dice and laughing loudly. The mariachis are gath ing around Mapache.. Lyle shifts in his chair to look at 198 MAPACHE IS LAUGHING AND DRINKING. The German. leans c to Zamorra and speaks in Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: Do you know these Americans?

dialogues.speaker: ZAMORRA
dialogues.text: No. The German settles back in his.chair and. begins placing a cigarette in a holder.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR AND LYLE LOOK SUSPICIOUSLY AROUND AT THE MEXI
dialogues.text: in the cantina. The other men tired from the trail only half listen to them as the girl serves beer.

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: Probably talking about us behind our backs. 200 DUTCH TURNS TO PIKE WHO IS QUAFFING a large beer.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I'm down to about twenty in silver...

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: The G3neralisimo has cleaned this part a of the country ...He ought to have it to spare.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Generalisimo hell -- he's just a damn bandit grabbing all he can for himself.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: (GRINNING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like some others I could mention?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: No sir -- we don't.hang nobody or torture them -- I hope the people here kick him and the rest of the scum like him right into-their graves.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL SITTING QUIETLY WITH HIS GLASS OF BEER WATCHES
dialogues.text: MAPACHE, his eyes burning with hatred.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: We will if it takes a thousand years: Then suddenly, he reacts to the sound of a girl's voice o scene.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Vamos:...te va. gustar el Alenman: Angel. spins around in his chair watching as: 202 TWO PRETTY MEXICAN GIRLS, TERESA AND RASA, laughing a giggling, pass-the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: .Teresa; He reaches out and grabs the better looking of the two by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: LYLE, (OS)
dialogues.text: Hey,. boy...you know them cuties? Teresa recognizes him,: then pulls away,

dialogues.speaker: ROSA
dialogues.text: Llamo los otros!

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: No, Vete, ahorita vengo; Pike and Dutch tense as Angel stands and jerks her toward him, -

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Let her go! 203 ANGEL LOOKS AT THE GIRL, furious and hurt..

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: Djaste el pueblo;

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Si deje el pinche pueblo. Y ahora vivo con el generalisimo; She jerks away from Angel and starts toward the other tab

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Angel. watches her go. In the b.g.,the group of Mariachis playing loudly have moved around Mapache's table.. No one there seems. to have seen the action.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Take it easy! He places a hand on Angel's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (to Angel) Que pasa::

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: His sweetheart --

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (still. watching Teresa) "She was my woman and she left the village.,

dialogues.speaker: 20L . TERESA SPLITS THE MARIACHIS AND STEPS-UP BESIDE EL
dialogues.text: and begins kissing his ear..

dialogues.speaker: TECTOR
dialogues.text: (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure ain't your woman no more.'

dialogues.speaker: LYLE "
dialogues.text: Just look at her licking that, big devil's ear. Angel watches, his rage growing, then stands -- Pike goes for-him., .. but too late..

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: (HISSES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put a! In a split second he draws and fires.

dialogues.speaker: THE BULLET FROM THE FORTY-FIVE CATCHES. HER IN THE STOMAC
dialogues.text: and hurls her to the floor. The others at the table duck for cover, their guns coming out.

dialogues.text: into the side of his head dropping him onto the floor, kn ing him out. The others stand, hands an -theirguns,

dialogues.speaker: ARE STANDING WITH THEIR GUNS COVERING PIKE AND THE OTHERS
dialogues.text: Mapache and the'others slowly rise, look at Angel, now realizing who shot the girl. 208 MAPACHE STARTS TOWARDS THEM. He pushes over chairs an people aside as he approaches the group. Zamorra9 the Ger and other members of his retinue are close on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE AND THE OTHERS ARE SILENT AND UNMOVING AS MAPACH
dialogues.text: up to the'table and quickly scans the group.. Angel gets his knees9 Mapache kicks him in the.head and when Angel. back, stamps him several times with his boot,, steps away One of Mapache's men starts to bash Angel's head with a r butt,. Mapache stops the man with a gesture,. then turns the others.

dialogues.speaker: MAPACHE
dialogues.text: Qua basura es este? Mapache again. kicks Angel..

dialogues.speaker: ZAMORRA
dialogues.text: Why did he try to kill His Excellency...?

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: He didn't, he was. after the girl... Mapache is having difficulty understanding. He looks at Z'amorra with a puzzled expression.

dialogues.speaker: ZAMORRA
dialogues.text: La.muchacha,..

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Era su novia; The Mexicans immediately respond to Dutch's explanation. Both Z.amorra and Mapache smile.

dialogues.speaker: O MAP ACHE
dialogues.text: (PLEASED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fiancee??...

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: He went a little crazy when he saw her with you. Mapache laughs. His ego is pleased with the idea that.he had taken someone's woman. He turns and explains grandly in Spanish to the rest of. the cantina.

dialogues.speaker: MA PA CHE
dialogues.text: Mato su vieja porque salio con El Mapache; The soldiers in the cantina laugh and ad lib their respon
210 PIKE. AND DUTCH TRY TO SMILE as do the Gorch brothers 211 MOHR IGNORES them, looking with interest at the U.S.. .45 pistols that the men are wearing.

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: (.to Pike) Are you men in Agua Verde for business? PIKE. Thought we might sell a few horses.

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: You must have been associated with the American Army, is that riot so? Tector and Lyle snicker slightly at the remark. Mapache a Zamorra turn, listening carefully to the conversation. The cantina is silent.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: -No -- were not associated with anyone...

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: I see,..1 was curious because of.the equipment which you are carrying. (as they look at him) That pistol is restricted for use'by army personnel. It can't be purchased or even owned... legally.

dialogues.speaker: -PIKE
dialogues.text: (GUARDEDLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? - -

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: You're surprised at my interest? (then as Pike doesn't answer) Weapons are a specialty of mine. Mohr bows his head slightly and clicks his heels barely a

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: I am Commander Frederick Mohr-of the Imperial German. Army. For the last six- months I have been in Mexico helping fight against the revolutionaries. 212. ANGEL ON THE FLOOR IS CONSCIOUS, but uimoving., list what is being said. Several of Mapache's men stand around

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: Unfortunately your government has chosen to aid the rabble in their so-called struggle for liberty...

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: I. never heard of any American troops fighting down here...

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: They are aiding in diplomatic channels... It would be very useful to us if we knew of Americans who did not share their government's naive sentiments.

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: We have vez"y'few sentiments in common with our government.

dialogues.speaker: MAPACHE
dialogues.text: Qua diga?

dialogues.speaker: MOHR
dialogues.text: (Xn Spanish) Generalisimo, I think we should ask these gentlemen to have a drink with us. And Pike, understanding. that much Spanish, smiles as we.

dialogues.speaker: A MARIACHI IS BLOWING HARD AND SAD INTO A TINY BRASS
dialogues.text: TRUMPET AS he looks at the body of Teresa being dragged out. Emma and.Rosa'are still very much in evidence..

dialogues.speaker: AT MAPACHE'S TABLE, PIKE, DUTCH, LYLE, TECTOR AND SYK
dialogues.text: all seated at the raised table on the dais..,. Mapache se at one end is tired and looks half asleep,. In the b.g. Angel can be seen still on the floor. A coupl of guards are sitting near him. 2,15 SEVERAL MARS. ARE SPREAD OUT on the table. Emma and Rosa crying softly, watch as the dead body of th girl. is dragged through a door at one end of the room. Zamorra is seated.next to the German listening intently,

dialogues.speaker: PIKE
dialogues.text: Of all those garrison rail spurs that ofie is the easiest to hit -- But I've got to figure where we can get out with. the wagon.

As the woman exits, Dutch stands and empties a bucket of water over' himself -and the others. They all g with relief. All have towels around their waists and none are completely sober. Pike's leg is heavily scarred and h is in pain. He stands and drinks, gets closer to the fire massaging his leg.

dialogues.text: Suddenly Pike embraces her and pulls her to the bed. They begin to make love, then: THE DOOR SMASHES OUN AND LUKE, a skinny bad mouthed Texan steps into the room, a_double barreled shot gun in his hands ready to fire. AURORA SCREAMS and throws herself in front of Pike. Luke fires, the charge killing her as Pike dives out of bed -- jumping for his gun on a nearby table. LUKE FIRES AGAIN, the blast catching Pike across the thig and knee. Pike goes down. Luke crosses to the bed and sits watching him writhing almost bleeding to death on th floor.

dialogues.text: She had a husband and I should have had enough sense to kill him. He wasn't around and I got careless. One night he.walked in on us - - got her with the first shot. He caught me here with the second then the damndd coward turned and ran.

dialogues.text: Not yet but there-hasn't been.a day or an hour that I haven't thought about getting him - - he didn't want that woman he just. wanted to kill somebody - - well, he killed her - - not me and I'll see him dead for it.
